Graphical abstract Pt nanocluster-loaded metal oxides, in situ pre-reduced under H2 at 500°C, were tested for the dehydrogenation of aliphatic secondary alcohols in the liquid phase. The activity for dehydrogenation of 2-octanol depended strongly on the acid–base character of the support oxide, and amphoteric oxides, especially γ-Al2O3, gave high activity. For a series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different Pt particle size, the turnover frequency (TOF) per surface Pt increases with decreasing Pt particle size, suggesting that low-coordinated Pt sites and metal/support interface play important roles in the catalytic cycle. The most active catalyst, Pt/Al2O3 with Pt particle size of 1.4nm, acted as reusable heterogeneous catalyst for dehydrogenation of aliphatic secondary alcohols to afford corresponding ketones. Pt/Al2O3 showed higher activity than other M/Al2O3 (Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Re, Ir, Au) catalysts and showed two orders of magnitude higher turnover number (TON) than previously reported Pt catalysts for alcohol oxidation. On the basis of the mechanistic studies by in situ infrared (IR) and kinetic experiments, the following cooperative mechanism is proposed: (1) reaction of an alcohol with Lewis acid (Alδ+)–base (AlOδ−) pair site of alumina yields an alkoxide on the Alδ+ site and a proton on the AlOδ− site, (2) CH dissociation of the alkoxide by Pt0 site to form PtH and a ketone, (3) protolysis of PtH by a neighboring proton to release H2 gas. The mechanism provides fundamental reasons for the higher activity of Pt on the acid–base bifunctional support (Al2O3) than those on basic and acidic one. Keywords Alcohols Cooperative catalysis Dehydrogenation Nanoclusters Platinum 1 Introduction Oxidation of alcohols to carbonyl compounds is a fundamental organic transformation. To meet environmental and economical acceptability, much effort has been devoted to heterogeneous catalytic systems for aerobic oxidation of alcohols [1–3]. However, the development of a novel catalyst system exhibiting high TON for the oxidation of non-activated alcohols, such as aliphatic and alicyclic alcohols, using recyclable catalysts still remains a major challenge. Platinum (Pt)-based catalysts [1–8] have been one of the most effective heterogeneous catalysts for aerobic oxidation of aliphatic alcohols, but their TONs were still low (TON=17−234). For a large-scale production of carbonyl compounds, oxidant-free catalytic dehydrogenation of alcohols is ideal from viewpoints of atom efficiency and safety of the reaction. This reaction is also of current interest as a potential method for hydrogen production from biomass products. Acceptor-free dehydrogenation of alcohols using homogeneous Ru [9,10] and Ir [11–13] catalysts has been reported as effective systems, but these systems suffer from drawbacks such as difficulties in catalyst reuse and requirement of acid or base additives. There are a few reports on heterogeneous Pt catalysts for the oxidant-free dehydrogenation of alcohols, but they suffer from low yields of carbonyl compounds and limited scope (2-propanol and cyclohexanol) [14,15]. Although heterogeneous Ru [16–18], Ir [19], Au [20], Ag [21,22], Cu [23,24], Co [25] and Ni [26] catalysts were reported to be effective, rational design of new heterogeneous catalyst for this reaction is difficult due to a lack of fundamental information on the structure–activity relationship and reaction mechanism. Notably, several homogeneous catalysts for the acceptor-free dehydrogenation of alcohols were rationally designed by a concept of “bifunctional catalysis”, where coordinatively unsaturated metal center acts as a CH activation site while a basic site in a ligand abstract proton from a OH group [9–13]. For example, a Ru PNN pincer catalyst developed by Milstein possesses a cooperative basic site in the β position to the metal which facilitates binding of the alcohol substrate to give alkoxide intermediate [9]. A Cp * Ir complex catalyst developed by Fujita et al. also has an acid–base conjugate pair site adjacent to a coordinatively unsaturated Ir site. In the case of metal nanoclusters with a few nm in diameter, a decrease in the particle size leads to an increase in the ratio of corner and edge sites (coordinatively unsaturated sites) relative to terrace sites. Knowing the fact that amphoteric metal oxides, such as alumina, have acid–base conjugate pair sites on the surface, the alumina surface might act as cooperative ligand that abstract proton from OH group of alcohol. In our previous studies, we reported that the Ag metal cluster [22] or Ni metal nanoparticle [26] supported on the acid–base bifunctional support (alumina) were effective for the dehydrogenation of alcohols and proposed that the catalytic activity was driven by metal-support bifunctional catalysis. In our continuous efforts to develop more effective catalyst and to establish a general catalyst design concept, we report herein that Pt nanocluster-loaded alumina shows two orders of magnitude higher TON than the Ag and Ni catalysts for the acceptor-free alcohol dehydrogenation of aliphatic secondary alcohols to ketones. Studies on structure–activity relationship will clarify that low-coordinated Pt0 site and acid–base sites on the support surface are indispensable for this catalytic system. Spectroscopic and kinetic studies will show a cooperative catalytic mechanism between the Pt0 site and the acid–base sites of the Al2O3 surface. The cooperative mechanism is essentially consistent with those proposed in our previous studies on Ag/Al2O3 [22] and Ni/Al2O3 [26], which suggests that the metal–acid–base cooperative catalysis is a general concept for the design of Al2O3-supported metal catalysts for the title reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Commercially available organic and inorganic compounds (from Tokyo Chemical Industry, Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Kishida Chemical, or Mitsuwa Chemicals) were used without further purification. 2-Propanol-O-d, (CH3)2CHOD with 98atom% D and 2-propanol-2-d1 (CH3)2CDOH with 99.4atom% D were purchased from Aldrich. The GC (Shimadzu GC-14B) and GCMS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010) analyses were carried out with Ultra ALLOY capillary column UA+-5 (Frontier Laboratories Ltd.) or CP-PoraBOND Q capillary column (Varian) using nitrogen as the carrier gas. 2.2 Catalyst preparation γ-Al2O3 (with surface area of 124m2 g−1) was prepared by calcination of γ-AlOOH (Catapal B Alumina purchased from Sasol) for 3h at 900°C. SiO2 (Q-10, 300m2 g−1) was supplied from Fuji Silysia Chemical Ltd. TiO2 (JRC-TIO4, 50m2 g−1), MgO (JRC-MGO-3, 19m2 g−1), CeO2 (JRC-CEO3, 81m2 g−1), and SiO2–Al2O3 (JRC-SAL-2, Al2O3 =13.75wt%, 560m2 g−1) were supplied from Catalysis Society of Japan. Active carbon (296m2 g−1) was purchased from Kishida Chemical. A commercial Pt-loaded carbon catalyst was purchased from N.E. Chemcat, Corporation. Precursors of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with Pt content of 5wt% were prepared by an impregnation method; a mixture of γ-Al2O3 and an aqueous HNO3 solution of Pt(NH3)2(NO3)2 was evaporated at 50°C, followed by drying at 90°C for 12h, and by calcined in air at different calcination temperatures (T cal). Before each catalytic experiment, a pre-reduced catalyst (Pt/Al2O3) was prepared by in situ pre-reduction of the precursor in a glass (Pyrex or quartz) tube under a flow of H2 (20cm3 min−1) at different reduction temperatures (T H2) for 0.5h. TiO2, CeO2, SiO2, SiO2–Al2O3, C (active carbon), and MgO-supported Pt catalysts with Pt content of 5wt% were prepared by the same method. The catalysts are designated as Pt/Al2O3-x nm, where x is the metal particle size. Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm was used as a standard catalyst. Preparation conditions (T cal and T H2) are summarized in Tables 1 and 2 . γ-Al2O3-supported metal catalysts M/γ-Al2O3 (M=Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Pd, Rh, Ag, Ir) with metal loading of 5wt% were prepared by impregnation method in the similar manner as Pt/Al2O3 using aqueous solution of metal nitrates (for Co, Ni, Cu), RuCl3, IrCl3·nH2O, NH4ReO4 or aqueous HNO3 solution of Rh(NO3)3 or Pd(NO3)2. Au/γ-Al2O3 (Au=1wt%) was prepared by the deposition–precipitation method with HAuCl4. 2.3 Characterization The number of surface metal atoms in Pt catalysts, pre-reduced in H2 at T H2, was estimated from the CO uptake of the samples at room temperature using the pulse-adsorption of CO in a flow of He by BELCAT (BELL Japan Inc.). According to the method of Tanabe et al. [27], the CO adsorption experiments for the Pt-loaded basic oxides (MgO and CeO2) were carried out at −78°C. The average particle size listed in Tables 1 and 2 was calculated from the CO uptake assuming that CO was adsorbed on the surface of spherical Pt particles at CO/(surface Pt atom)=1/1 stoichiometry. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements were carried out by using a JEOL JEM-2100F TEM operated at 200kV. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments of CO2 and NH3 were carried out using BELCAT. Prior to each experiment, catalyst (0.1g) was heated in a flow of He (20cm3 min−1) at 500°C for 0.5h, followed by cooling to 40°C under He flow. Then, the catalyst was exposed to a flow of 100% CO2 or 5% NH3/He for 10min. After purged in He for 0.5h, the catalyst was heated linearly at 10°Cmin−1 to 650°C in a flow of He, and CO2 (m/e =44) and NH3 (m/e =17) in outlet gas were analyzed by the mass spectrometer (BELMASS). 2.4 Condition of catalytic reactions Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm was used as a standard catalyst. After the pre-reduction at 500°C, we carried out catalytic tests using a batch-type reactor without exposing the catalyst to air as follows. The mixture of o-xylene (1g), alcohol (1mmol), and n-dodecane (0.2mmol) was injected to the pre-reduced catalyst inside the reactor (cylindrical glass tube) through a septum inlet, followed by filling N2. Then, the resulting mixture was stirred under reflux; typically, the bath temperature was 155°C and reaction temperature was ca 144°C. Conversion and yields of products were determined by GC using n-dodecane as an internal standard. Progress of the reaction was monitored by GC analysis of aliquots (ca. 0.02g). The initial rate of reaction was measured under the conditions where the conversion was below 47%. The products were identified by GC–MS equipped with the same column as GC and by comparison with commercially pure products. GC analysis of the gas-phase product (H2) was carried out by the mass spectrometer (BELMASS). 2.5 In situ IR In situ IR spectra were recorded on a JASCO FT/IR-4200 equipped with a quartz IR cell connected to a conventional flow reaction system. The sample was pressed into a 40mg of self-supporting wafer (ϕ =2cm) and mounted into the quartz IR cell with CaF2 windows. Spectra were measured accumulating 15 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1. A reference spectrum of the catalyst wafer in He taken at measurement temperature was subtracted from each spectrum. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst disk was heated in H2 flow (100cm3 min−1) at 500°C for 0.5h, followed by cooling to 40°C and purging with He. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Pt/Al2O3 Table 1 summarizes the preparation conditions and the mean size of Pt metal particles, estimated by the CO adsorption method, for a series of Pt catalysts loaded on various metal oxides. To prepare the catalysts with the same Pt content (5wt%) and similar Pt particle size but with different support materials, temperatures of calcination (T cal) and reduction (T H2) were changed as shown in Table 1. As shown in Table 2, a series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different Pt particle size were also prepared by changing T cal of the catalyst precursor (PtO x /Al2O3). The Pt particle size of Pt/Al2O3 increased with increases in the calcination temperature. Consequently, Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different Pt particle size were prepared. The catalysts are designated as Pt/Al2O3-x nm, where x is the Pt particle sizes (nm). To confirm the accuracy of the particle size from the CO adsorption experiments, we carried out TEM analysis of two samples (Pt/Al2O3-7.8nm and Pt/Al2O3-12nm). The particle size distributions are shown in Fig. S1 (in the Supporting Information) and volume–area mean diameter [28] of Pt particle is listed in Table 2. The mean diameters estimated by TEM analysis are consistent with those estimated by the CO adsorption experiment within the experimental error of TEM analysis, confirming the accuracy of the mean Pt size from the CO adsorption. Thus, a series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different Pt particle size were prepared. 3.2 Catalyst screening We studied influence of various catalyst parameters on the catalytic activity for dehydrogenation of 2-octanol 1a to 2-octanone 2a under the same reaction conditions (under N2 in reflux conditions for 0.5h). First, Al2O3-supported Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Re, Ir, Au catalysts were tested in dehydrogenation of 1a under the same reaction conditions (Fig. 1 ). It is found that the Pt catalyst (Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm) showed the highest reaction rate. Table 3 shows the results for dehydrogenation of 1a using a series of supported Pt catalysts with the same loading (5wt%). The activity depended strongly on the support material. Among various Pt catalysts supported on various supports (Al2O3, MgO, CeO2, TiO2, SiO2–Al2O3, SiO2, SnO2, C), Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm gave the highest activity. Al2O3 itself was completely inactive (not shown). Unreduced catalyst precursor of Pt-loaded Al2O3 calcined at 550°C (platinum oxides-loaded Al2O3, PtO x /Al2O3) was also ineffective. To optimize Pt particle size of Pt/Al2O3, the catalysts with different Pt particle size (1.4–12.0nm) were tested. The initial formation rate of 2a is shown in Table 2. In the particle size range of 1.4–12.0nm, the catalyst with the smallest Pt size (Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm) gave the highest reaction rate. From the catalyst optimization experiments, it is found that Al2O3-supported Pt catalyst with the smallest Pt particle size, Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm, is the best catalyst. As shown in Table 3, Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm showed more than seven times larger reaction rate than a commercial Pt-loaded carbon (from N.E. Chemcat). 3.3 Catalytic performance of Pt/γ-Al2O3 With the Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm catalyst, we studied reusability and a scope of the present system. In the dehydrogenation of cyclooctanol by Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm (0.5mol%) for 0.5h, the yields of gas-phase H2 (21%) and cyclooctanone (21%) were identical to the alcohol conversion (21%), indicating that H2 was generated quantitatively. After 3h, the yield of cyclooctanone was 97% (Fig. 2 , cycle 1). The reaction was completely terminated by removal of the catalyst from the reaction mixture after 0.5h; further heating of the filtrate for 3h under the reflux condition did not increase the yield. ICP analysis of the filtrate confirmed that the content of Pt in the solution was below the detection limit (0.06ppm). These results confirm that the reaction is attributed to the heterogeneous catalysis of Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm. After the reaction of cycle 1 in Fig. 2, followed by decantation for 1h, the solution was removed by a syringe through a septum inlet. Then, the catalyst inside a glass reactor was washed with acetone under N2 atmosphere to remove residual reactant and product. As shown in Fig. 2, the recovered catalyst thus obtained was reused at least four times without any indication of catalyst deactivation. The scope of the Pt/Al2O3-catalyzed dehydrogenation of alcohols is shown in Table 4 . In the presence of Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm (0.01–1mol%), various aliphatic secondary alcohols were selectively converted to the corresponding ketones with good to high yield (78–97%). Because H2 escapes from the reaction mixture into the gas phase, the overall endothermic dehydrogenation reaction is driven to the product side, leading to such a high conversion of alcohols to ketones. Catalytic properties of Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm for the selective oxidation of 2-octanol and cyclooctanol are compared with those of previous Pt catalysts in Table 5 . TON of our system was more than 10 times higher than those of the previous systems. We have previously reported that Ag nanocluster-loaded Al2O3 (Ag/Al2O3) is effective for oxidant-free dehydrogenation of alcohols [21]. Recently, we also reported Co nanoparticle-loaded TiO2 (Co/TiO2) [25] and Ni nanoparticle-loaded Al2O3 (Ni/Al2O3) as effective catalysts for this reaction [26]. For the reaction of 2-octanol, Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm shows two orders of magnitude higher TON (8400) than Ag/Al2O3 (25) [21], Co/TiO2 (78) [25], and Ni/Al2O3 (82) [26]. 3.4 Structure–activity relationship First, we discuss the effect of the oxidation states of Pt species on the catalytic activity. As shown in Table 3, platinum oxides-loaded Al2O3 (PtO x /Al2O3) was ineffective. In addition, the activity of the Pt metal cluster-loaded Al2O3 catalyst (Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm) was decreased by exposing the catalyst to air at room temperature (Table 3). This suggests that the metallic Pt0 species on the surface of Pt nanoclusters are the active species and re-oxidation of them results in the catalyst deactivation. Therefore, we can conclude that the surface Pt0 species are catalytically important species compared with oxidic Pt species. Next, using the catalytic results for the dehydrogenation of 2-octanol 1a and the dispersion of Pt estimated by CO adsorption, we can discuss the effects of Pt metal particle size and support oxides on the turnover frequency (TOF) with respect to the number of surface Pt atoms. As shown in Table 2, a series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different particle size were prepared, and TOF was determined. As shown in Fig. 3 , the TOF per surface Pt atom decreases with the mean diameter of Pt particles. Taking into account the fact that the fraction of low-coordinated Pt atoms (per all the surface Pt atoms) and metal/support perimeter length decreases with the particle size, the result suggests that the present catalytic system requires the low-coordinated surface Pt0 atoms and metal/support perimeter sites. Considering a well-known tendency that metal-catalyzed reactions involving CH and CH bonds (dehydrogenation) are less sensitive to metal particle size than reactions involving CC, NN, or CO bonds [33], catalytic importance of the metal/support perimeter sites may be the primary origin of the size effect in Fig. 3. If the metal/support perimeter sites play an important role, the activity should depend strongly on the type of support material. Next, we discuss the effect of the support. As listed in Table 1, we prepared a series of metal oxides-supported Pt catalysts with the same Pt content (5wt%) and near particle size (1.8–2.7nm). TOF (from Table 3) is plotted in Fig. 4 as a function of the electronegativity of the support metal oxide, which is generally used as a parameter of acidity of metal oxides [29]. A volcano-type relationship between the catalytic activity and the electronegativity of the support is obtained. Basic (MgO) and acidic (SiO2–Al2O3, SnO2) supports showed lower activity than amphoteric oxide support such as Al2O3. Note that Pt nanoclusters on a nearly neutral support (SiO2) showed 27 times lower TOF than those on an amphoteric support (Al2O3). NH3- and CO2-TPD results of the Al2O3 support are shown in Fig. S2. The results show amphoteric property of γ-Al2O3. These results suggest that both acidic and basic sites on the Al2O3 support are necessary for this reaction. To verify this hypothesis, we studied the poisoning effects of acidic or basic additives in the reaction mixture on the activity of Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm for the dehydrogenation of 1a. As shown in Fig. 5 , the presence of catalytic amount of acidic (acetic acid) and basic (pyridine) additives decreased the reaction rate. It is established that adsorption of acetic acid on Al2O3 results in the formation of the acetate ion at the acid–base pair site (Alδ+ Oδ− site) [30], while pyridine adsorbs on the surface Lewis acid site (exposed Alδ+ cation) of Al2O3 [31]. Therefore, the result of the poisoning experiment indicates that the acid–base pair site and the surface Lewis acid site are necessary for this reaction. 3.5 Reaction mechanism To study a reaction mechanism, we studied in situ IR experiments at 40°C. Fig. 6 shows the spectra of adsorbed species formed by the adsorption of 2-propanol-O-d, (CH3)2CHOD, on Al2O3 pre-heated in a flow of He at 500°C for 0.5h. In the spectra, bands due to 2-propoxide groups are predominant: 2970cm−1 (methyl asymmetric CH stretching), 2940cm−1 (methyl asymmetric CH stretching), 2874cm−1 (coupling of α-CH stretching and methyl symmetric CH stretching), 2740cm−1 (α-CH stretching), 1465cm−1 (methyl asymmetric deformation), 1376cm−1 (methyl symmetric deformation), 1328cm−1 (α-CH deformation), 1166 and 1130cm−1 (CO/CC coupled stretching). Broad and multiple bands in a range 2300–2750cm−1 due to protonic AlOD groups [34] are also observed. The broad feature due to the OD stretching vibration indicates an acidic (protonic) nature of the AlOD groups. The band due to OH deformation of undissociated 2-propanol (1280cm−1) is hardly observed. These results indicate the presence of aluminum alkoxide species, (CH3)2CHOAl, and acidic AlOD groups on the alumina surface and the absence of non-dissociatively adsorbed 2-propanol. Intensities of the bands due to (CH3)2CHOAl and AlOD species slightly decreased with time in a flow of He, but these bands still remained after 900s, which indicates that these species were relatively stable. The following surface reaction (Eq. (1)) should account for the experimental result; the reaction of 2-propanol with AlOδ− group (basic site on alumina) results in the formation of 2-propoxide coordinated to the unsaturated Alδ+ site (Lewis acid site) and AlOD group. (1) ( CH 3 ) 2 CHOD + Al δ + + Al O δ - → ( CH 3 ) 2 CHOAl + AlOD The same IR experiment was conducted using Pt/Al2O3 pre-reduced in H2 at 500°C for 0.5h (Fig. 7 A). The preparation method of this sample is the same as that of the Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm catalyst. The bands due to (CH3)2CHOAl and AlOD species were also observed in the IR spectra for Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm. It is noteworthy that the band positions for Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm are exactly the same, indicating that 2-propoxide is predominantly adsorbed on the support surface. The presence of other 2-propanol species, such as those on Pt, as minor species could not be declined, because signals of such species could be actually covered by those of species on the Al2O3. Fig. 7B shows the height of the bands due to 2-propoxide, adsorbed acetone and AlOD species as a function of time in a flow of He. After the formation of 2-propoxide species (t =120s), intensity of the bands due to the 2-propoxide species gradually decreased and a new band at 1700cm−1 due to CO stretching of adsorbed acetone appeared and its intensity increased with time. The same IR results were observed for the reaction of 2-propanol, (CH3)2CHOH, on Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm (Fig. 8 A). These results suggest that 2-propoxide undergoes CH cleavage, resulting in the formation of acetone (Eq. (2)). Note that 2-propoxide species on Pt-free alumina did not convert to acetone (Fig. 6). Thus, metallic Pt is necessary in the CH dissociation step. The kinetic curve in Fig. 7B clearly shows that the formation rate of 2-propoxide is faster than its consumption rate. Therefore, the dissociative chemisorption to form the alcoholate intermediates is relatively fast, and the hydride abstraction from the alcoholates is a kinetically more important step. (2) R 2 CHOAl + Pt 0 → ( CH 3 ) 2 CO + PtH + Al The intensity of the band due to AlOD groups (2300–2750cm−1) decreased with time, indicating the consumption of the acidic AlOD groups. The following pathway should account for this result; protolysis of PtHδ− species with the protonic Dδ+ species in an adjacent AlOD group can occur to release dihydrogen (HD) accompanied by the regenerations of the Pt0 site and the basic AlOδ− site of alumina (Eq. (3)). (3) PtH + AlOD → HD + Pt 0 + Al O δ - In order to prove the reaction mechanism quantitatively, we compared the rate of dehydrogenation of the 2-propoxide intermediate with the rate of catalytic dehydrogenation of 2-propanol by Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm at 40°C. Fig. 8B shows the time course of the number of 2-propoxide estimated from IR band area in a range 1350–1400cm−1 and the adsorption coefficient (1.63cmμmol−1) of adsorbed 2-propanol species reported in our previous study [32]. Initially, the number of 2-propoxide species decreased linearly with time. The transient rate for the consumption of 2-propoxide estimated from the initial slope of the line was 1.3mmolh−1 g−1 [35]. On the other hand, the kinetic curve for the liquid-phase catalytic test in o-xylene as a solvent is shown in Fig. 9 . Under the condition where the conversion of 2-propanol was below 8%, the yield of acetone increased linearly with reaction time. From the slope of the initial straight line, the rate of 2-propanol dehydrogenation was estimated to be 2.7mmolh−1 g−1. This value is in the same order of magnitude as the transient rate for the consumption of 2-propoxide, indicating that the 2-propoxide species on Al2O3 is the reaction intermediate of the catalytic reaction. The larger value for the catalytic rate than the transient rate may be ascribed to the difference in the reactor and conditions; the liquid-phase catalytic test was carried out using a batch-type reactor in the presence of o-xylene as a solvent, while the transient surface reaction of adsorbed 2-propoxide was carried out in a flow of He. As recently reviewed by Andanson and Baiker [36], an in situ IR study on heterogeneous catalysis in liquid phase can be performed. We believe that an in situ IR study in the liquid phase would give more reliable transient rate. Finally, we studied kinetic isotope effect in the liquid-phase 2-propanol dehydrogenation by Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm at 40°C. Fig. 8 shows the kinetic curves for (CH3)2CHOH, (CH3)2CHOD and (CH3)2CDOH. The yield of acetone linearly increased with the reaction time. Thus, the zero-order rate constants were estimated from the slope. Using the rate constant for (CH3)2CHOH and (CH3)2CHOD, the kinetic isotope effect (k H/k D) of 2.4 was estimated. The kinetic isotope effect from the data of (CH3)2CHOH and (CH3)2CDOH was 3.5. These results indicate that the OH and α-CH dissociations of 2-propanol are kinetically important steps, and the α-CH dissociation step is the rate-limiting step. This conclusion is consistent with those from the IR study in Fig. 7B. Based on the mechanistic experiments for the dehydrogenation of alcohols by Pt/Al2O3-1.4nm, a possible reaction mechanism is presented in Fig. 10 . Initially, a basic AlOδ− group of alumina abstract a proton from alcohol to afford alkoxide group on an adjacent Alδ+ site (Lewis acid site) and a proton on the AlOδ− site (AlOHδ+). An alkoxide at the interface between a Pt nanocluster and alumina surface undergo hydride abstraction to yield hydride species on Pt (PtH) and acetone as the rate-determining step. Then, the PtH species undergoes a protolysis by a neighboring AlOHδ+ site to release H2 gas, accompanied by the regenerations of the Pt0 site and the basic AlOδ− site of alumina. On the basis of the proposed mechanism, the strong effect of support acid–base nature on the Pt catalyzed alcohol dehydrogenation (Fig. 4) can be explained as follows. The abstraction of proton in alcohol by the metal oxide surface requires basic site. Thus, on the Pt-loaded acidic oxides, dissociative adsorption of 2-propanol is limited by weak nucleophilic character of the metal oxide surface. On the other hand, protonic (electrophilic) nature of the OH groups on a basic oxide is weaker than that on the amphoteric oxide (alumina), and the protolysis of PtHδ− species with an adjacent OH group is slow. It is important to note that the cooperative mechanism is essentially consistent with those proposed in our previous studies on Ag/Al2O3 [22] and Ni/Al2O3 [26], which suggests that the metal–acid–base cooperative catalysis is a general concept for the design of Al2O3-supported metal catalysts for the title reaction. 4 Conclusion Alumina-supported Pt metal nanocluster was found to act as heterogeneous and reusable catalyst for the acceptor-free oxidation of secondary alcohols. Among various supports, amphoteric supports (such as alumina) having both acidic and basic sites gave higher activity than acidic and basic supports. The TOF per surface Pt increases with decreasing Pt particle size. These results suggest that low-coordinated Pt0 sites and metal/support interface play important roles in the catalytic cycle. On the basis of in situ IR and kinetic experiments, the following mechanism is proposed: (1) reaction of an alcohol with Lewis acid (Alδ+)–base (AlOδ−) pair site of alumina yields an alkoxide on the Alδ+ site and a proton on the AlOδ− site, (2) CH dissociation of the alkoxide by the low-coordinated Pt0 site to form PtH and ketone, (3) protolysis of PtH by a neighboring proton to release H2 gas, accompanied by the regenerations of the Pt0 site and the basic AlOδ− site of alumina. Fundamental information will lead to a design of new heterogeneous catalysts for hydrogen-transfer reactions by controlling the cluster size and acid–base bifunctional nature of support materials. coredata.dc:description: Pt nanocluster-loaded metal oxides, in situ pre-reduced under H2 at 500°C, were tested for the dehydrogenation of aliphatic secondary alcohols in the liquid phase. The activity for dehydrogenation of 2-octanol depended strongly on the acid–base character of the support oxide, and amphoteric oxides, especially γ-Al2O3, gave high activity. For a series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different Pt particle size, the turnover frequency (TOF) per surface Pt increases with decreasing Pt particle size, suggesting that low-coordinated Pt sites and metal/support interface play important roles in the catalytic cycle. The most active catalyst, Pt/Al2O3 with Pt particle size of 1.4nm, acted as reusable heterogeneous catalyst for dehydrogenation of aliphatic secondary alcohols to afford corresponding ketones. Pt/Al2O3 showed higher activity than other M/Al2O3 (Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Re, Ir, Au) catalysts and showed two orders of magnitude higher turnover number (TON) than previously reported Pt catalysts for alcohol oxidation. On the basis of the mechanistic studies by in situ infrared (IR) and kinetic experiments, the following cooperative mechanism is proposed: (1) reaction of an alcohol with Lewis acid (Alδ+)–base (AlOδ−) pair site of alumina yields an alkoxide on the Alδ+ site and a proton on the AlOδ− site, (2) CH dissociation of the alkoxide by Pt0 site to form PtH and a ketone, (3) protolysis of PtH by a neighboring proton to release H2 gas. The mechanism provides fundamental reasons for the higher activity of Pt on the acid–base bifunctional support (Al2O3) than those on basic and acidic one.
coredata.dc:title: Size- and support-dependent Pt nanocluster catalysis for oxidant-free dehydrogenation of alcohols
